name.text: 23.6.2.5 Revision of the exponential form of a complex number

questiontext.text:
Clearly, we can now rewrite the trigonometric Fourier series \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left( a_n \cos n \omega_0 t + b_n \sin n \omega_0 t \right) \] as \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left( c_n e^{i n \omega_0 t} + c_n^* e^{-i n \omega_0 t} \right) \] A neater, and particularly concise, form of this expression can be obtained as follows:

Firstly write \( \dfrac{a_0}{2} = c_0\) (which is consistent with the general definition of \(c_n\) since \(b_0 = 0\)). The second term in the summation \[ \sum_{n=1}^\infty c_n^*e^{-i n \omega_0 t} = c_1^* e^{-i \omega_0 t} + c_2^*e^{-2i \omega_0 t} + \dots \] can be written, if we define \( c_{-n} = c_n^* = \dfrac{1}{2} (a_n + ib_n) \), as \[ c_{-1} e^{-i \omega_0 t} + c_{-2} e^{-2i \omega_0 t} + c_{-3} e^{-3i \omega_0 t} +\dots \sum_{n=-1}^{-\infty} c_n e^{i n \omega_0 t} \]

Hence the trigonometric Fourier series can be written \[ c_0 + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c_n e^{i n \omega_0 t} + \sum_{n=-1}^{-\infty} c_n e^{i n \omega_0 t} \] or in the very concise form \[ \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} c_n e^{i n \omega_0 t}. \] The complex Fourier coefficients \(c_n\) can be readily obtained as follows using the usual Fourier series definitions for \(a_n\) and \(b_n\).

Firstly, \[ c_0 = \dfrac{a_0}{2} = \dfrac{1}{T} \int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^{\frac{T}{2}} f(t) \hspace{0.1cm} dt \] For \( n = 1, 2, 3, \dots\) we have \[ \begin{align} c_n &= d\frac{1}{2}(a_n- i b_n)=d\frac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t)(\cos n\omega_0 t - i \sin n\omega_0 t) dt \\ &= \dfrac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t) e^{- i n\omega_0t} dt \end{align} \] Also for \( n = 1, 2, 3, \dots\) we have \[ c_{-n}={c^*_n}=\dfrac{1}{2}(a_n+ i b_n)=\dfrac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t) e^{i n\omega_0 t} dt \] This last expression is equivalent to stating that for \(n=-1,-2,-3,\dots\) \[ c_n=\dfrac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t) e^{-i n\omega_0t}dt \] The three equations above can be contained in the one expression \[ c_n=\dfrac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t) e^{-i n\omega_0t} dt\qquad \text{ for}\quad n=0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\pm 3,\dots \] The results of this discussion are summarised in the following Key Point.

Key Point

Fourier Series in Complex Form

A function \(f(t)\) of period \(T\) has a complex Fourier series \[ f(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty c_n e^{ i n \omega_0 t}\qquad\text{ where}\qquad c_n=\frac{1}{T}\int_{-\frac{T}{2}}^\frac{T}{2} f(t) e^{- i n\omega_0t}dt\] For the special case \(T=2\pi\), so that \( \omega_0=1\), these formulae become particularly simple: \[f(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty c_n e^{i nt}\qquad c_n=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi f(t) e^{-\text{ i}nt} dt\]
